title: Brave mum who lost legs and fingers to sepsis determined to continue nursing
text:

If there was a prize for Britain’s bravest, most inspirational nurse – few could compete with the amazing Karen Allen-Ross.

A woman who was robbed of her legs and fingers by a horrific condition yet who has vowed to get back to nursing.

It is just days since her final operation in 15 months against sepsis and she is already speaking to bosses about returning to work.

Courageous Karen, 54, who has been a nurse for 30 years, was fitted with ­prosthetic legs and taught herself to write again.

She said: “It has been a challenging and ­emotional journey but I feel I’m out the other side. I’m stronger than I ever thought I was. If this happened to anyone else in my family I know I’d be an emotional wreck.

(Image: PA REAL LIFE)

“Nothing will stop me. I’m alive and I have got to live my life. I’ve got a lot of years left. I’m going to be here to see my daughters marry and become a grandparent. I’ve learned to live for each day and live life to the full.”

Karen’s horrific experience began in July last year. She had just been on a four-day holiday to North Wales, which included a trip on the 5,101ft Zip World Velocity 2, reputedly the world’s fastest zip line, a Christmas gift from her lorry driver partner Lyndon Paget.

Karen had returned to work at Derriford Hospital, Plymouth, but became ill and spent three days feeling achy and shivery, with a high temperature.

She woke up at 2am feeling too hot to sleep. She said: “I got up to use the loo and noticed my feet were really aching, it was very painful to walk. I was quite breathless and became really frightened. I was banging on the banister to let Lyndon know I couldn’t get upstairs.

(Image: Barry Gomer)

“I said to him ‘I think I’m going to die.’”

Lyndon drove her to A&E at Derriford, where she has worked for 16 years. Her blood pressure was very low and she was taken to the resuscitation ward. Karen knew low blood pressure affects the supply to organs and said: “I was scared but I was in the best place.”

An intensive care unit ­doctor told her she had sepsis and she had a catheter fitted and was put on an IV drip.

She was told she may have an infection in the bowel and that evening she had a six-hour operation to remove part of her bowel and spleen.

Karen still does not know why she developed sepsis although it may be related to her ­previously undiagnosed Crohn’s disease, an inflammatory bowel ­condition.

(Image: PA REAL LIFE)

She spent five days in a medically ­induced coma and doctors warned her family she might not make it. When she came round her kidneys were ­failing so she was also put on dialysis to clean her blood.

Karen said: “My feet and fingers were black. My legs were all mushy. I knew the surgeon wouldn’t hold back in telling me the truth. The medical team had to work out where the healthy tissue was compared with the dead ­tissue, so they were asking me to walk.

“It was the most horrific time I can remember. The pain was like a red hot poker going up through my heel and up the back of my leg.

“My fingers were really hard. If you rapped them on the table it was like banging a piece of wood on them. There was no feeling.

(Image: PA REAL LIFE)

“One of the legs was dead and there was a risk of the sepsis coming back in the other.

“I was told if I did not have them amputated I wouldn’t survive and I knew it was best just to have both my legs off. On August 28, Karen had both legs amputated.

During her recovery she had ­unstinting support from Lyndon, 56, and her daughters, receptionist Gaby, 23, and ­healthcare assistant Rebecca, 24.

Recalling the day after her amputations, she said: “My first thought was that my stumps looked beautiful. The shape was beautiful.”

She recalled: “Those ten days after my first operation were so awful for my family. To me, they were a blur, but I know Lyndon was really struggling.”

(Image: PA REAL LIFE)

In September last year Karen was ­finally allowed home but five more operations followed to remove her fingers and graft skin from her abdomen on to her hands. One last op, an abdomen procedure, happened on October 1, this year.

Karen, who has been left with two thumbs and half of her forefinger on her left hand, said: “In some ways, I found losing dexterity in my hands harder than losing my legs. You do everything with your hands and you take your fingers for granted until they’re not there.

“I’ve had to teach myself how to write again. I couldn’t hold a knife but I’ve taught myself to do it. I’ve started ­wrapping presents for people’s birthdays. It’s working out how to do things ­differently. I can do things, I just do them slower and in a different way.”

Karen learned to walk with her ­prosthetic limbs, with the help of parallel bars, on the same day she had them fitted in February.

(Image: PA REAL LIFE)

She said: “It was amazing, a very ­emotional moment. I was very lucky as I had a great physiotherapist and assistant who pushed me. By July I was able to walk on my own just using sticks. It has been a gradual process.

“But I’m one of those people who needs to run before they can walk.”

Karen and Lyndon used to live an ­active life before she contracted sepsis, ­including walks together along the coast.

She is determined to get back to doing what she loves. With the help of pals, who have raised nearly £14,000 using JustGiving, she will soon be fitted with more lightweight prosthetics.

She said: “The new prosthetics cost about £7,500 each, but I’ll have to wait for about two years for my stumps to shrink for them to settle down and get down to the size they will stay.

(Image: PA REAL LIFE)

“I’m not planning any kind of prosthetic for my fingers. I can manage without them. It’s ­difficult but there’s always a way around things.

"Now I’ve had my final surgery, my next step is to get a car, so I can have my independence and get back to work.

"I won’t be able to do what I was doing before but my boss has been very supportive and is finding something for me.”

Meanwhile, Karen is working hard to make people aware of the signs of sepsis, including slurred speech, extreme shivering and muscle pain, not passing urine, severe breathlessness and mottled skin, all signs that she had herself.

She said: “People are still dying from sepsis. It’s such a dangerous thing and it has such a huge impact on people and their families.

“It helps me to talk about it. If I can help one person by letting them know what happened, that will be enough.”

For more on sepsis see sepsistrust.org. Give to Karen’s fund go to justgiving.com/crowdfunding/thesepsissurvivor.

description: EXCLUSIVE: Karen Allen-Ross, who had been a nurse for 30 years, has just recovered from her final surgery and wants to work again
